awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  P2C2--Testing the Tropical Storm and Tropical Cyclone Masking Hypotheses: Advancing Speleothem Reconstruction of Paleotempestology and Paleohydrology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to use speleothems from caves on the Yucatan Peninsula to reconstruct quantitative precipitation and tropical cyclone (TC) records affecting the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico regions spanning hundreds of thousands of years.

The success of such reconstructions depends on understanding the relationship between local precipitation amount and precipitation delta 18-Oxygen isotope values (i.e. the amount effect) and  how this relationship is preserved in stalagmite deposits. TC precipitation can shift the amount effect and it has been hypothesized that TC rain may therefore bias quantitative stalagmite delta 18-Oxygen isotope precipitation records (i.e. the TC masking hypothesis). 

Recent studies based on stalagmite delta 18-Oxygen isotope precipitation records, however, suggest that TC variability was linked to the collapse of the ancient Maya civilization (i.e., the tropical storm hypothesis).  Available stalagmite delta 18-Oxygen isotope precipitation records to test this hypothesis have not yet been replicated and their precipitation estimates may reflect TC masking.  Replication, furthermore, may be hindered by chronological uncertainty, the lack of equilibrium stalagmite delta 18-Oxygen isotope values and regional climate variability. 

The researchers therefore will: (i) apply a promising approach for replication of available stalagmite delta 18-Oxygen isotope based precipitation records during selected intervals spanning the last 2000 years; (ii) examine quantitatively the TC masking influence on the amount effect and on stalagmite precipitation records; and (iii) test the tropical storm hypothesis by applying an ultrahigh resolution sampling approach to detect the particular isotopic signature from individual TCs in three known stalagmites (i.e., CH-1, Chaac, Itzamna).

The potential Broader Impacts include improved understanding of tropical cyclone (TC)-climate relationships under different climate states and over long timescales.  Such understanding is critical for accurate projections and TC risk assessment and mitigation in a changing climate. This project supports a female lead investigator at an undergraduate liberal arts college. It will provide significant research experience for several undergraduates and the researchers have a strong history of supporting women and underrepresented minority students.  

One of the lead researchers is an early-career Hispanic faculty member and this project would support the work of this researcher and two female Hispanic PhD students. This work would potentially help further develop methods for speleothem-based paleotempestology and would highlight the need to consider TC masking in other tropical speleothem records. Finally, this work will be of interest to the archaeology research community as it can help address the role of TCs in societal changes in Latin America.

por.por_cntn:
We have examined the oxygen isotopic composition (δ18O values) of drip water, rainfall, and groundwater in the Rio Secreto cave system, located in the Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico. The Rio Secreto cave system is a large semi-inundated underground system that despite being visited by over 10,000 people every year, is preserved in a pristine state. We established a long-term monitoring system in this cave system, that included the characterization of air temperature, groundwater temperature, dripwater temperature, air relative humidity, dripwater pH and electrical conductivity, and the hydrogen and oxygen isotopic composition of groundwater and dripwater. We also grew calcite artificially on glass plates to study the equilibrium isotopic fractionation between stalagmite calcite and the oxygen isotopic composition of dripwater. The main motivation of this project was to determine the implications of drip water hydrology for the reconstruction of rainfall amount, droughts and tropical cyclone activity going back in time from years to hundreds of thousands of years, using stalagmites as paleoclimate archives. Stalagmites are secondary calcium carbonate deposits that form from the combination of rainfall and limestone, in regions where the solid land surface is composed of limestone predominantly. In this project we found that stalagmites from the R?o Secreto cave faithfully record the oxygen isotopic composition of rainfall, and that this, in turn, reflects the amount of rainfall. We also found that the number of rainfall events and the quantity of rainfall that stalagmites record depend on the characteristics of the bedrock, including its permeability and size of the groundwater reservoirs. Interestingly, we found that in this region the conventional approach used by hydrologists to determine groundwater recharge consisting in quantifying the evapotranspiration to precipitation fluxes underestimates the effective recharge of the aquifer. This is because rainfall greatly escapes evaporation due to the high permeability of the rock in the region. Our project results suggest that it is possible to reconstruct precipitation amount and the influence of tropical cyclones in the region by obtaining high resolution stalagmite oxygen isotope records. Our project results also suggest that available stalagmite oxygen isotopic records from the Maya lowlands that have an annual resolution may underestimate the intensity of paleo-drought events, such as those that occurred during the Terminal Classic Period associated with the disintegration of the Maya civilization. For more detailed information please refer to the two publications generated from this project so far: Lases-Hernandez et al., GCA 2019, GCA 2020. We are currently working on a third publication derived from this project concerning the oxygen isotopic equilibrium fractionation between stalagmite calcite and dripwater.
